author: Il Sole 24 ORE
title: Sciopero, Landini: vogliamo rivoltare il Paese come un guanto - Il Sole 24 ORE
text: Bologna, 29 nov. (askanews) - "Oggi è la giornata della rivolta sociale, certo. Dal nostro punto di vista vogliamo rivoltare come un guanto questo Paese e per rivoltare come un guanto questo Paese c'è bisogno della partecipazione di tutte le persone". Lo ha detto il segretario generale della Cgil, Maurizio Landini, prima dell'inizio del corteo a Bologna nella giornata dello sciopero indetto da Cgil e Uil. "La rivolta sociale - ha proseguito Landini - per noi significa proprio dire che ognuno non deve voltarsi da un'altra parte di fronte alle ingiustizie. Anzi, deve passare l'idea che il problema mio è il problema di tutti e che solo mettendoci insieme possiamo cambiare questa situazione e credo che la risposta che sta arrivando, per le notizie che abbiamo dalle piazze di tutto il Paese, è di una mobilitazione come da tempo non si vedeva. Per quello che ci riguarda questo significa non limitarci alla protesta oggi perché oggi inizia un percorso di mobilitazione per rivoltare come un guanto questo Paese. Basta ingiustizie, basta precarietà". Riproduzione riservata ©

author: NewsBreak Original
title: ‘It’s no joke’: East side delivered one-two weather punch
text:
By Brad Hamilton Dave Nethers ,
15 hours ago
(WJW) — A steady pounding of lake effect snow fell across Ohio’s primary snow belt, dropping a fresh coating on top of mounds of snow and ice left from last week.
Communities including Ashtabula and Lake County not only got walloped once again with as much as eight inches of additional snow but the season’s coldest temperatures dealt a double blow.
Biden pardons these 4 Ohioans, veterans Low double-digit temperatures were made to feel like minus-two with bitter wind gusts at times higher than 30 miles an hour directly off of the lake.
“About the last what ten-fifteen years it hasn’t been this bad at all but now all of a sudden its back,” said Jonathan Moore, a lifelong resident of Ashtabula who was carefully driving for the city’s transportation service on Thursday trying to get senior citizens safely to and from doctors appointments.
“You have to be careful. The roads are slick. Some people have to go to a dialysis center on wheelchairs, walkers and you have to be extra careful with them because its slick snow is deep and some of them can’t move as well as they used to,” said Moore.
Younger residents of the area say they cannot remember a season this brutal in years.
But for long-time residents, it reminds them of winters they experienced here along the Lake Erie Coastline when they were younger.
“To me this is how it was when I was a kid – when I was a kid going to school this was every day. No schools were closed nothing,” said Jeff Moore
Moore, who has tried for years to make some money plowing snow, said this was a great year for plow drivers.
Fernando Roboes said he had been plowing since 2 a.m. Thursday.
Jimmy Dimora sentence commuted by President Biden “You have just go to go over again like you start early…you have got to go over it again. The first place you did you have to go back again,” said Roboes.
While the snowfall on Thursday was not necessarily paralyzing, particularly by primary snowbelt standards, it did make for sloppy roads and slow going.
The Ohio Department of Transportation was plowing and treating highways around the clock as were municipal crews, those in Ashtabula trying to clear 90 miles of laned roads through the city.
And winter does not officially start for another nine days.

author: Ground News
title: Ground News - This artwork grows the longer it's on display, and it's making history at Sculpture by the Sea
text: This artwork grows the longer it's on display, and it's making history at Sculpture by the Sea Noongar artist Sharyn Egan has returned to Sculpture by the Sea in Cottesloe, now in its 20th year. Her sculpture, titled Balga Boola – Bigsmob Balga, grows throughout the duration of the exhibition into a blossoming field of Balga trees. The 67-year-old artist was named the 2024 Tourism WA Invited Aboriginal Artist. author: Editorial La República S.A.S.
title: Se activa una alerta roja de lluvia torrencial en la región de Huelva, suroeste de España
text:
Tras los estragos que dejó Dana en Valencia, se reportó una alerta roja de lluvia torrencial en la región de Huelva, al suroeste de España.
En la ciudad de Cartaya, ya se reportaron lluvias de 127mm desde la medianoche del jueves, lo que equivaldría a cerca de dos meses de precipitaciones en condiciones normales.
La alerta naranja aún permanece en la zona del norte de Valencia, el sur de Cataluña y todas las islas Baleares. En estas zonas, se esperan tormentas eléctricas durante la jornada del viernes antes de que baje la intensidad (prevista para la mañana del sábado).
“El Dana [sistema meteorológico] no ha terminado, hay provincias con alerta naranja y roja. Extrememos las precauciones y estemos siempre atentos a la información que nos den las autoridades”, afirmó el primer ministro español, Pedro Sánchez.
Valencia contabiliza 202 muertes Los efectos de Dana en la comunidad valenciana ya dejan una cifra superior a 200 fallecimientos, esto según el Centro Integrado de Coordinación Operativa del Ministerio de Interior.
Aún no se sabe a cuánto ascienden las pérdidas económicas por las inundaciones. Centenares de establecimientos y miles de carros quedaron atrapados entre el lodo y los escombros luego de las torrenciales lluvias del martes.

author: Kate Rix
title: Robots face phantoms in engineering showcase on Northeastern’s Oakland campus
text: Featured Northeastern students put their projects to the test as the robots jerked and cruised their way through cardboard mazes during the final stage of the semester’s project. OAKLAND, Calif. — It was the phantom objects that stumped even the best-performing robots during the Cornerstone of Engineering showcase at Northeastern University’s Oakland campus. Students recorded progress with their phones as custom-made robots jerked and cruised their way through cardboard mazes — the final stage of the semester’s project. The robot that Sebastian Leyko built with partner Aviana Fenton was doing fine until the maze challenge. “We generally didn’t have any issues until we reached challenge three,” Leyko says. “First we had a turn issue with our robot, and then it saw phantom objects.” In other words, the tissue box-sized machine made of a small circuit board, wheels and a battery pack came to a halt for no apparent reason. Glitches like this are to be expected when building a robot from scratch and releasing it into unfamiliar conditions, says Leila Keyvani, associate teaching professor of engineering. The point of the project is to challenge the small machines that students have made with new twists, turns and obstacles. “Some robots are inconsistent,” says Keyvani, who taught Cornerstone of Engineering 1 this semester. “But they’ve done a great job with all the little intricacies.” Other bumps along the way include motors that spin at different rates, fading battery packs and power surges when batteries are replaced. Over the last six weeks students worked in teams of two to build robots. They put their own spin on designs using the same materials: circuit boards, wires, solderable breadboards, wheels, AA-battery packs and ping pong balls. That last component acts like a caster wheel so the robot can move left to right. Otherwise students would have to incorporate another set of wheels. But it was proving troublesome for Alp Ayata’s robot on the third maze. “It’s having a hard time on straightaways,” says Ayata, a bioengineering major from Hoboken, New Jersey. “The ping pong ball causes the robot to swerve a little to the left as it drives,” he says as his robot stalled out for the fourth time. “It gets to that location and it loses its traction.” Student teams made the mazes, which each had difficulty ratings based on their turns and dead ends. The maze Ayata’s robot struggled with was a seven out of eight on the difficulty scale. Teams earned points for how their robots handle each maze — the one they made themselves, a second maze of their choosing and a third that Keyvani picked for them — and submitted a video to show how they did. “Once it got so close,” Ayata says, viewing a video on his phone. “It made it through the whole maze, but at the very end this back part got stuck on the wall, which stopped it from turning all the way and it got stuck at the very end. Worst case, we can submit that.” At this final stage, there’s nothing Ayata or any of the other 63 students in Keyvani’s class can do to change their robots. But they can change the code that tells the circuit boards what to do. Alyssa Roberts and Claire Montegut used a flowchart to create the logic structure for their robot’s code, which tells the sensors what to do under different conditions. “That really helped us figure out how we wanted our robot to think through this maze challenge,” says Roberts, an engineering major from Boston. “It helped us guide our code.” Gabriel Aroesty’s robot was crashing into a cardboard wall when it tried to turn right. “It isn’t turning enough,” said Aroesty, an engineering major from Boston who, like many of the other engineering students in the class, will spend the spring semester at the London campus. “So we changed the code so it would make a longer turn.” Try, fail, try again and fail again. That’s what engineering is all about, Keyvani says. “The main thing for them to realize is that it’s an iterative process,” she says. “It takes time to produce and it involves programming, hardware and troubleshooting.”

author: Vanessa Barone
title: Praça do Jardim Paulista ganha playgroun... | VEJA SÃO PAULO
text:
A Praça Coração de Maria , no Jardim Paulista, vai ganhar um parquinho infantil público, graças ao empenho de um grupo de 20 estudantes entre oito e nove anos. As crianças, que são alunas da Escola Concept, de ensino bilíngue e que fica em frente à praça, arrecadaram R$29 mil para a realização da obra. E o resultado poderá ser conhecido na próxima segunda (23), a partir das 8h30, quando o espaço será oficialmente entregue à população – após cinco meses de trabalho.
A ideia do parquinho surgiu durante as atividades em classe, quando os alunos foram estimulados a refletir sobre a falta de playgrounds públicos na cidade. “Tudo partiu das crianças: desde o interesse de elaborar um espaço coletivo de brincadeira à campanha de arrecadação da quantia necessária para a sua construção”, afirma Luciana Shimizu, coordenadora de performance acadêmica da Escola Concept.
Alunos em atividade para criar protótipos dos brinquedos a serem instalados no playground da praça (Divulgação/Divulgação) E todas essas ações ainda viraram material de estudo, como conta Iris Trindade, educadora e responsável pelo projeto. “Além da colaboração, nós desenvolvemos habilidades matemáticas ao lidar com a campanha financeira”. Os alunos também tiveram de exercitar a escrita, para divulgar a campanha com clareza, e as habilidades motoras, para criar protótipos de brinquedos para abastecer o parquinho. A arrecadação do dinheiro para as obras veio de financiamento coletivo e da venda de rifas e doces, feita pelos estudantes, na última Festa Junina da escola.
Continua após a publicidade Inauguração playground da Praça Coração de Maria . Dia 23/09, às 8h30. Avenida 9 de Julho, Jardim Paulista
